instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: previous issue, changed out <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> because of an intermittent display problem. It worked before, but since I changed it out it no longer displays or backlights. I was careful with heat, and used a poly tant 330uf same size package from fast fox board. Saw display wasn't working after this, and tried another one. Obviously chances are slim that they were both bad. I did notice that the new ones said case-b2-sm1 whereas the old one didn't say sm1. It just had case-b2-sm (no "1"). Ideas? Could it be the cap I chose?

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>=1.07V
Finally got a little more info from customer. She said when it goes to sleep over night, in the morning, she opens it and it resets the whole system...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Could be anything. Got 1.35/1.5V on <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR>? It could be 100 other things, any knocked off resistor/ESD damage could cause this.

Also not hot air should be used in this proces, can easily be done with normal soldering iron, much safer.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Uggh any suggestion what I should tell her since it actually displayed and lit up when she gave it to me, now it doesnt even do that? I really hope I can find the cause to at least get it to display and send it back nfnf in the same condition it came to me.
